div2.head: DECLARATION.

opener.salute: Fixing the per diem pay of Members and Officers of the Convention.

div2.p: Section 1. Be it declared by the delegates of the people of the State of Texas in Convention assembled, That the members and officers (not to include messengers and porters) of said Convention, shall receive from the State Treasury, as a compensation for their services, the sum of eight dollars per day; and the members likewise eight dollars for every twenty-five miles travel coming to and going from the Convention, and the messengers and porters the sum of four dollars per day.

Sec. 2. Be it further declared, That the sum of one hundred and twenty-five thousand dollars, or so much thereof as shall be necessary, is hereby appropriated out of any moneys in the Treasury not other-
wise appropriated, to pay the mileage and per diem aforesaid.

Sec. 3. Be it further declared, That the certificate of the Secretary of the Convention will be sufficient to authorize the Comptroller to draw upon the Treasurer for such sums as may be due the members and officers aforesaid, and that this declaration take effect from its passage.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
Urging Congress to transfer certain powers from the Military Com-
mander of the Fifth Military District to this Convention.

div2.p:
Resolved, 1. That in the opinion of this Convention, it is necessary in the State, to a fair administration of the laws of Congress upon the subject of the Reconstruction of the States lately in rebellion, to so change the provisions of said laws as to transfer from the Com-
Ordinances Passed by themander of the Fifth Military District to this Convention, the power and authority to appoint and to remove Registrars, for ascertaining and recording the qualified voters of the State of Texas.
Resolved, 2. That the Convention respectfully, but earnestly, urge upon the Congress of the United States the change indicated in the preceding resolution, at the earliest practical moment.

Resolved, 3. That the President of this Convention transmit to the President of the Senate and Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Congress of the United States, copies of these resolutions.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
For the furnishing of Paschal’s Digest of the Laws of Texas to Com-
mittees, and opening the State Library to Members of the Conven-
tion.

div2.p:
Resolved, 1. That the Provisional Secretary of State is hereby re-
spectfully requested to furnish the Chairman of each standing Com-
mittee, for the use of his committee, one copy of “Paschal’s Annotated Digest of the Laws of Texas;” the same to be returned to the State Library on the adjournment of this Convention.
2. That the same officer is hereby respectfully requested to direct the State Librarian to open the State Library to the members of this Convention at all reasonable hours.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
On printing two hundred copies of the Reconstruction Laws of Con-
gress.

div2.p: Resolved, That the Committee on Printing be hereby authorized and instructed to contract for, and have printed as speedily as practicable, two hundred copies of the Reconstruction Laws of Congress, for the use of the members of this body, and that said committee report, etc.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
For the purchase of five hundred copies of Paschal’s Annotated Con-
stitution of the United States.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the Secretary be authorized to purchase for the use of the members of this Convention, and for the use of the State and future Legislatures, one hundred and fifty copies of “Paschal’s Anno-
tated Constitution of the United States,” and upon his certificate ap-
pended to the proper voucher, the Comptroller be required to draw his warrant upon the Treasurer for the amount necessary to cover the said purchase. Provided, however, that not more than one dollar and eighty cents per copy shall be paid therefor.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: For Special Committee to examine the administration and financial condition of the State Penitentiary.

div2.p: Resolved, That the President of this Convention appoint a special committee of five to investigate the administration of the financial affairs of the State Penitentiary, since August, 1866, and that they report the same, showing the difference, if any, between the assets at the date referred to and the present time; and that said committee have power to take testimony and to send for persons, records and papers.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Authorizing the Secretary to order two thousand copies of the Austin Daily Republican, five hundred copies of the Tri-Weekly Free Press, and four hundred copies of the San Antonio Daily Express, for the use of the Members of this Convention.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the Secretary of this Convention order two thousand copies of the Daily Republican, of Austin, at five cents per copy; five hundred copies of the Tri-Weekly Free Press, of San
Ordinances Passed by theAntonio; and four hundred copies of the San Antonio Daily Express, for the use of the members of this Convention. Provided, That these papers shall publish the journals of this Convention, and that the price of the two last named papers shall not exceed eight cents per copy.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Dispensing with the reading of the Report of the Superintendent of Education.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the reading of the report of the Superintendent of Education be dispensed with; that the same be referred to the Com-
mittee on Education; and that the Committee on Printing be directed to contract for the printing of five hundred copies of the same for the use of this body.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Permitting certain officers herein named to occupy seats upon the floor of the House.

div2.p: Resolved, 1. That the Commanding General District of Texas, the Governor and Judges of the Supreme and District Courts, have the privilege of the floor of the Convention Hall within the bar.
2. That any member shall have the privilege of inviting a friend to a seat within the bar of the Hall.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Tendering thanks to F. Flake, Esq., Editor of Galveston Bulletin.

div2.p:
Whereas, F. Flake, Esq., editor and proprietor of Flake’s Daily Gal-
veston Bulletin, has kindly proposed to furnish, gratis, the members of this Convention with copies of his excellent newspaper during the session of this Convention, therefore be it

Resolved, That the thanks of the members of this Convention be, and they are hereby respectfully tendered to Mr. Flake, that his kind proposition is accepted, and that we assure him that the same is duly appreciated.

opener.salute: Declaring that the Committee on Penitentiary, or any one or more of them, may proceed to Huntsville to perform their duties.

div3.head: SUBSTITUTE.
div3.p: Resolved, That the Committee to examine the Penitentiary of the State, or any one or more of the members thereof, at their discretion, be and they are hereby authorized to proceed to Huntsville, to carry into effect the orders of this Convention, and that they be authorized to employ an accountant to aid them in their investigation, at a price not to exceed eight dollars per diem.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Empowering the Committee on Political or Legislative Department to employ a clerk.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the Committee on Political or Legislative Depart-
ment be empowered to employ a clerk at a compensation of four dollars per diem, provided that said clerk be employed on any other commit-
tee that needs his services, when not employed on Committee on Politi-
cal or Legislative Department.

opener.salute:
Urging upon the Congress of the United States the necessity of ap-
pointing a force in each county for the Suppression of Lawlessness and Violence.

div3.head: PREAMBLE.
div3.p:
Whereas, Lawlessness and crime exists to such an alarming ex-
Ordinances Passed by thetent in portions of this State, it is deemed proper to do all in the power of this Convention to protect life and property, and for the suppression of crime; therefore

Resolved, 1. That this Convention respectfully urge upon the Con-
gress of the United States the necessity of authorizing the organization by this body of a militia force in the several counties in this State, to act in conjunction with and under the direction of the Military Com-
mander therein, for the protection of the lives and property of the citizens now every day being preyed upon by assassins and robbers to an extent unparalleled in the history of civilized communities in times of peace; and which, if not speedily arrested, must result in the destruc-
tion of social order.

Resolved, 2. That if protection is not speedily provided in some form by the National Government to the loyal and law-abiding citizens of Texas, they will be compelled, in the exercise of the sacred right of self-
defense, to organize for their own protection.

Resolved, 3. That this Convention have full confidence in Brevet Major General J. J. Reynolds, Commander of the District of Texas, and that to the extent of the means placed at his disposal he will give pro-
tection and preserve peace.

Resolved, 4. That the President of this Convention be requested to forward by telegraph, at expense of Contingent fund of the Con-
vention, to the President of the Senate and Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Congress of the United States, copies of these resolutions.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Authorizing the Committee on Penitentiary to inquire into the Laws under which Convicts are held.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the Committee appointed to investigate the financial condition of the State Penitentiary be, and are hereby authorized to inquire into and ascertain the cause for which each convict was com-
mitted, and for what length of time.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute:
Amendatory of a Declaration appropriating one hundred and twenty-
five thousand dollars for the pay of Members of the Convention and Officers.

div2.p:
Section 1. Be it declared by the delegates of the people of Texas in Convention assembled, That the caption of said declaration, of which this is amendatory, shall be and the same is hereby so amended as to read: “A declaration making an appropriation for the per diem pay and mileage of the members and per diem pay of the officers of the Convention, and for the printing and contingent expenses of the Con-
vention.”

Sec. 2. Be it further declared, That section second of the declara-
tion, of which this is amendatory, shall hereafter read and be as fol-
lows: “That the sum of one hundred and twenty-five thousand dollars, or so much thereof as shall be necessary, is hereby appropriated out of any moneys in the Treasury, not otherwise appropriated, to pay the mileage and per diem aforesaid, and the printing and contingent ex-
penses of the Convention.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Requesting the Commanding General to approve the appropriation of one hundred and twenty-five thousand dollars to defray expenses of Convention.

div2.p:
Be it resolved, 1. That the Commanding General of the Fifth Mili-
tary District be, and he is hereby requested to approve the action of this Convention by his order appropriating the sum of one hundred and twenty-five thousand dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, from the Treasury of the State of Texas, to defray the expenses of this Convention.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Authorizing the publication of the Debates of the Convention.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the Committee on Printing be instructed to
Ordinances Passed by thecontract with the Austin Republican for the publication of the debates of this Convention in the two thousand copies of that paper, already sub-
scribed to, provided the charge shall not exceed eight cents per copy.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Instructing Engrossing and Enrolling Clerks, when not engaged in the duties of their positions, to assist the Secretary.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the Enrolling and Engrossing Clerks of the Conven-
tion, when not engaged in the discharge of the regular duties of their respective offices, shall be employed as Assistant Secretaries, under the direction of the chief Secretary.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Ordering the printing of four hundred copies of the Report of Wm. Alexander, Esq., late Attorney General of Texas.

div2.p: Resolved, That the Secretary be instructed to procure the report made by Wm. Alexander, while Attorney General to the Governor of the State, and that four hundred copies of the same be printed for the use of this Convention.

opener.salute: Defining the Powers of this Convention.

div3.head: SUBSTITUTE.
div3.p: Resolved, 1. That this Convention is assembled by the authority of and in obedience to the laws of the United States.

2. That this Convention possesses the power to frame a constitu-
tion and civil government for Texas; and that it is a question alone
Constitutional Convention.for the Convention to determine, what ordinances, declarations and resolutions are necessary and proper to carry out the expressed will of Congress.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Appropriating twenty-five thousand dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary for the apprehension of desperadoes.

div2.p:
Whereas, There exists all over the State of Texas a class of despera-
does engaged in theft, murder and robbery; and, whereas, it becomes of the greatest importance that such desperadoes be arrested and brought to justice, be it, therefore, declared that

1. That the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars, or so much there-
of as may be necessary, be, and the same is hereby appropriated out of any money in the State Treasury, not otherwise appropriated; and that the same be placed at the disposition of the Governor of Texas, to enable him to offer suitable rewards for the arrest and apprehension of such desperadoes, and to employ detectives to ferrit out their hiding places: and that this resolution be forwarded to the Commanding Gen-
eral of the Fifth Military District for approval.

Provided, That no part of the same shall be used unless the Military Commander of the District of Texas shall first be authorized to organ-
ize military commissions for the trial of offenders.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
Amending the rules governing the Convention, so that a simple Reso-
lution or Resolutions relating to the government of the Convention may be disposed of upon a vote at first reading.

div2.p: Resolved, That the following rule will be adopted, in addition to the rules already adopted for the government of the proceedings of this Convention:

That a simple resolution which only affects the personal rights or privileges of individual members of the Convention, or Resolutions relating solely to the internal government of the Houses, or relating
Ordinances Passed by theto the printing of documents which have been read in the Convention, may be disposed of by a vote on the first reading.
Resolved, further, That this rule be inserted among the general rules of the Convention, after the 24th section thereof.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Appropriating the sum of two hundred dollars to frame the portrait of General Sam. Houston.

div2.p:
Section 1. Be it Resolved, That the Executive, E. M. Pease, be re-
quested to procure a suitable frame to contain the portrait of the great father and statesman of Texas, General Sam. Houston.

Sec. 2. And that the sum of two hundred dollars is hereby appro-
priated to carry out this resolution.

Sec. 3. That the certificate of his Excellency E. M. Pease shall be a sufficient Toucher to authorize the Comptroller to draw his warrant upon the Treasurer for the amount of the costs of framing said por-
trait.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
Appropriating fifteen thousand dollars for the payment of the Civil Officers of the State appointed by Provisional Governor A. J. Ham-
ilton.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the sum of fifteen thousand dollars, or so much there-
of as may be sufficient, be, and the same is hereby appropriated to pay the unsettled balance due the Civil Officers of this State, appointed by Governor A. J. Hamilton; and that this resolution be forwarded by the President of the Convention, to Major General Buchanan, asking his approval of the same.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Suspending the sale by Police Courts of School Lands.

div2.p:
Be it Declared by the People of Texas in Convention assembled, That the sale of the School Lands by the Police Courts of the several counties of the State, as authorized by the act of the Legislature, approved No-
vember 1, 1866, is hereby suspended until some definite policy in ref-
erence thereto shall be established, in the re-organization of civil Gov-
ernment in the State: and that all sales that have been made under said law are null and void.

Be it further Declared by the Convention, That 150 copies of this Declaration be printed; and upon its adoption by the Convention, the Secretary transmit a copy thereof to the County Judge of each county in the State, for his guidance and direction.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Requesting Major-General J. J. Reynolds to cause to be estimated the Receipts in the Treasury and the Expenditures therefrom for the year ending 1st July, 1869, &c.

div2.p:
Resolved, That Brevet Major General J. J. Reynolds, Commanding District of Texas be, and he is respectfully requested to cause the proper accounting officer of the Civil Provisional Government to furnish for the information of this Convention, complete estimates of the probable receipts into the Treasury and expenditures therefrom, for the year ending 1st July, 1869, noting the appropriation made by the Command-
ing General of the Fifth Military District, by request of his Excellency the Governor, and of this Convention, in addition to those made by the Legislature of 1866.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
Appropriating four hundred dollars to pay the Expenses of Commit-
tee appointed to investigate the affairs of the Penitentiary.

div2.p:
Be it Declared, That the sum of four hundred dollars be, and the same is hereby appropriated out of the Contingent Fund of the
Ordinances Passed by theConvention, to pay the expenses of the Committee to investigate the State Penitentiary, travelling expenses, expenses of witnesses, &c.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Requesting Major General J. J. Reynolds to cause the Comptroller of Public Accounts to furnish statements as herein specified.

div2.p:
Resolved, That Brevet Major General J. J. Reynolds, commanding the District of Texas be, and is hereby respectfully requested to cause the Comptroller of Public Accounts of Texas to prepare and transmit for the use of this Convention, the following statements and informa-
tion, to wit:
1. Statement showing the assessment of taxes in each county in the State for the year 1867.
2. Estimate of costs of collection of taxes, under existing laws.
3. Amount collected upon assessment for 1867.
4. Statement of the different accounts, showing the receipts from the 4th September, 1867, and the balance in the different kinds of funds standing as credit of each account on 31st May, 1868.

5. Statement of warrants drawn by the Comptroller upon the Treas-
urer during the period commencing September 4, 1867, ending with 31st May, 1868.
6. Statement of public debt.
7. Reports of Railway Companies made to Comptroller under act of February 7, 1853.
8. Statement showing the present indebtedness of each Railroad Company to the State, and also what amount of interest has been paid; when, in what kind of funds paid, and amount remaining unpaid.
9. Statement of amounts paid for Asylum, from the establishment to the 1st June, 1868, and in what kind of funds paid.

10. Statements of amounts paid for Penitentiary, from its establish-
ment to 1st June, 1868; in what kind of funds paid.
Statement showing the amount and character of funds paid for School Lands during the existence of the rebellion.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
Providing for selecting Messrs. M. C. Hamilton and C. Caldwell to pro-
ceed to Washington, and lay before Congress certain matters herein specified.

div2.p: Resolved, That this Convention selects Messrs. M. C. Hamilton and C. Caldwell, members of this body, as a committee, with instructions to proceed to Washington without delay, and lay before Congress the condition of lawlessness and violence prevalent in this State, and urge the immediate necessity for action on the following matters:

First. The adoption of some law or regulation that will secure the filling of all provisional State offices with competent and loyal in-
cumbents.
Second. The organization of a loyal militia, to be placed under the direction and control of the loyal Provisional authorities of Texas.
Third. The appointment by this Convention of Registrars of voters previous to the coming election.

Fourth. Such other matters as may be referred to the action of Con-
gress by this Convention.

Resolved, 2. That the sum of eight hundred dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, be, and the same is hereby appropriated out of any funds at the disposition of this Convention, to pay the ex-
penses of travel of said Committee in going to and returning from Washington.

div2.head: DECLARATION,

opener.salute: Providing that no bond shall be required of the State in any suit now pending, or which may hereafter be instituted.

div2.p:
Be it declared by the Delegates of the people of Texas in Convention assembled, That no bond shall be required of the State in any suit now pending, or which may hereafter be instituted, to which the State may be a party, as a condition for the issuance of any writ to which the State may be otherwise entitled; and that this declaration take effect and be in force from and after the passage, until the adoption of some Consti-
tutional provision regulating and controlling the subject.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Ordering one thousand copies of the Austin Daily Republican, at eight cents per number, and five hundred copies of the San Antonio Free Press, at seven cents per number, and discontinuing other papers.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the Secretary be instructed to discontinue all news-
papers heretofore ordered for the use of this Convention, except one thousand copies of the Austin Daily Republican, at eight cents per number, and five hundred copies of the San Antonio tri-weekly Free Press, at seven cents per number, which he is authorized to continue; and, if these papers be continued, they publish the journals of the Con-
vention.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
Requesting the arrest of one C. C. Gillespie, Editor of Houston Tele-
graph, for advising the assassination of Morgan C. Hamilton and C. Caldwell.

div2.p:
Resolved, That Brevet Major General Reynolds be requested to arrest one C. C. Gillespie, the editor of a paper purporting to be the Daily Telegraph, of Houston, and have him arraigned before a Military Com-
mission, to answer for counselling and advising in his paper, bearing date of July 14, A. D. 1868, the assassination of Honorable M. C. Hamilton and C. Caldwell, members of this Convention.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
Providing for the appointment of a committee to proceed to Millican for the purpose of investigating the recent disturbance, and appro-
priating five hundred dollars for expenses of said Committee.

div2.p:
Resolved by the People of Texas, in Convention assembled, That a committee of three be appointed by the President of this Conven-
Constitutional Convention.tion to proceed to the town of Millican, for the purpose of investigat-
ing the cause of the late disturbance at that place, and report the result thereof to this body; that said Committee are invested with full power to summon such witnesses before them, and examine such papers as shall be necessary to elicit the desired information; that any and every Sheriff in the State shall execute any and every process, of whatever character, that may be issued by said Committee, and the Chairman of said Committee shall have power to swear witnesses; that the sum of five hundred dollars, or so much thereof as shall be necessary, be, and the same is hereby appropriated out of the Contingent fund of this Convention, for the purpose of defraying the expenses of said commit-
tee; that Brevet Major General Reynolds be, and is hereby respectfully requested to aid said committee in this investigation, by the protection, by an adequate escort of cavalry or infantry, as he may direct.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
Appropriating five hundred dollars for the arrest of the attempted as-
sassin of Judge Cooley.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the attention of the Governor be called to the gallant conduct of Frank Yung, Sheriff of Gillespie county, and his companion, Captain Alfred Hunter, who have succeeded in arresting the would-be assassin of Honorable C. Cooley; and the Governor is hereby respect-
fully requested to devote the sum of five hundred dollars out of the ap-
propriation of twenty-five thousand dollars, made for such purposes by this Convention, as a suitable recompense to the said Frank Yung and Alfred Hunter, for their efficient services.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Appropriating five hundred dollars to pay telegrams.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the President of this Convention be, and he is here-
by authorized to draw from the Contingent fund the sum of five hundred dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, to be used
Ordinances Passed by theby him in transmitting dispatches to, and paying for telegrams from our Commissioners at Washington.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Requesting the Congress of the United States to appoint a Committee to enquire into the condition of the State.

div2.p: Whereas, It is the desire of the loyal people of Texas that the people of the United States be correctly informed of the social and political condition of the people of this State; therefore,

Be it resolved by the delegates of the people of Texas in Convention assembled, That the Congress of the United States is hereby respectfully and most earnestly requested to send a committee of that honorable body into the State of Texas, to enquire into the condition of the State, to the end that the facts may be made known to the public in an authori-
tative manner.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
Requesting Brevet Major-General J. J. Reynolds to appoint one or more Commissioned Officers to participate in the investigation of the Milli-
can disturbance.

div2.p:
Resolved, That this Convention respectfully request Brevet Major-
General J. J. Reynolds, commanding District of Texas, to select one or more commissioned officers under his command, as he may deem proper, to participate with the committee appointed by this Convention, in the investigation of the late disturbance at Millican.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
For the payment of the per diem of Mr. Horne, a member of the Con-
Convention.

div2.p:
Resolved, That whereas William E. Horne, a member of this Convention, was sick at its assembling, and remained unable to get
Constitutional Convention.to his seat in this body, from such sickness, until a few weeks since;

Be it declared that the Secretary of this Convention do issue to the said William E. Horne a certificate for the time he was absent on ac-
count of sickness.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Appropriating fifteen thousand dollars to pay officers appointed by Provisional Governor A. J. Hamilton.

div2.p:
Be it resolved, That a declaration of this Convention, asking the as-
sent of General Buchanan to the payment of fifteen thousand dollars out of the treasury, for the settlement of claims of officers appointed by Provisional Governor Hamilton, be referred to General Reynolds for approval.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Referring a Resolution Appropriation of twenty-five thousand dollars to Major-General Reynolds.

div2.p: Be it resolved, That a resolution of this Convention, in reference to an appropriation of twenty-five thousand dollars, for paying suitable rewards for the apprehension of criminals, which was not endorsed by General Buchanan, be respectfully referred to General Reynolds for his approval.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Incorporating the Belleville, Hempstead, and Brazos Bridge Company.

div2.p: Be it declared by the Convention:

Section 1. That J. G. Bell and such other persons as he may associate with himself, are hereby incorporated under the name of
Ordinances Passed by thethe “Belleville, Hempstead, Brazos Bridge Company;” and, under such name, shall sue and be sued and have succession for thirty years.

Sec. 2. Said company shall have the right to construct a bridge of iron or wood, across the Brazos river, at or near a point where a straight line from the town of Belleville to the town of Hempstead, in Austin county, Texas, crosses the Brazos river.

Sec. 3. Said company shall construct said bridge in a good and sub-
stantial manner, within three years from the first day of January, A. D. 1869, and shall keep the same in good repair for the term of thirty years from the completion thereof; and to be ready, at all times, to pass all passengers, carriages, wagons, teams and stock that may wish to cross on said bridge; and be responsible, as common carriers, under the law, for any loss of property in transit over said bridge.

Sec. 4. That said company shall be entitled to charge and receive, from the completion of said bridge, for the term of thirty years, the following tolls from all persons who will cross themselves, or property, viz: Four horse or ox stage or wagon, loaded, fifty cents; for six horse or ox stage wagon, loaded, seventy-five cents; and for each additional pair of horses, mules or oxen attached to said wagons, twenty-five cents; single horse and buggy, thirty cents; two horse buggies, two horse or ox wagons, fifty cents; other vehicles in proportion; footman, five cents; cattle, five cents per head; hogs, sheep and goats, two cents per head; and other property, not mentioned, in proportion to the above rates.

Sec. 5. That no other bridge shall be constructed across the said Brazos river, for the space of thirty years, within five miles on a straight line up and down said Brazos river, from said bridge which said Belleville, Hempstead Brazos Bridge Company may construct; and that this declaration be and have effect from its passsage.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Authorizing the Secretary to pay Fred. Slaughter one dollar and fifty cents per day as mail carrier of the Convention.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the Secretary of the Convention be, and he is hereby authorized and required, to issue to Fred. Slaughter, the car-
rier of the mails to and from the Convention, a certificate for one dollar and fifty cents for each day which the said Fred. Slaughter
Constitutional Convention.has been so employed; and that the amount so certified in favor of said Slaughter shall be deducted out of the amount of the per diem pay due, by a previous resolution of the Convention, to the Postmaster of the Convention.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Authorizing the transcribing the Journals of the Convention.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the Secretary of the Convention be, and he is hereby authorized and required to have the Journals of the Convention in-
scribed in a bound volume, such as is commonly used in recording deeds, and said Secretary shall receive the sum of twenty cents for every hundred words of said Journal so inscribed, in addition to his per diem pay.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Requesting Congress to pass the International Railroad Bill.

div2.p:
Whereas, There is pending before Congress a Bill to aid in the con-
struction of the International Pacific Railroad, from Cairo, in Illinois, to the Rio Grande River, to authorize the consolidation of certain Rail-
road Companies, and to provide homesteads for laborers on said road; which bill contemplates aid by the United States, in the rapid construc-
tion of a continuous line of Railroad and Telegraph from Cairo, in Illi-
nois, through the south eastern portion of Missouri and central districts of Arkansas, Texas and Mexico, to San Blas on the Pacific ocean, and which enterprise, in the opinion of this Convention, ought to be encour-
aged; therefore,

Section 1. Be it declared, by the people of the State of Texas in Con-
vention assembled. That the Congress of the United States be requested to pass the Bill incorporating the said companies into the International Pacific Railroad, and granting said companies aid in Bonds for the con-
structing of the Railroad above mentioned as proposed in said Bill.

Section 2. That said companies, when incorporated by Congress as hereinbefore requested, shall have the right to vary the guage so
Ordinances Passed by theas to correspond to the guage from Cairo to the Texas line; also the right to build and operate a Telegraph line along said road.

Section 3. That said companies shall have the right of way through the State of Texas, and all the privileges, immunities and franchise within this State, as are now, or may hereafter be conceded to railroads under any general law of this State.

Provided, That this declaration shall not be considered as conferring any grant of lands to the companies incorporated, except such lands as may have, already, under some general law of the State, rightfully ac-
crued to the Brazos Branch Railroad Company or the Henderson, Mar-
shal and Jefferson Railroad Company.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: For the incorporation of the Houston City Railroad Company.

div2.p: Section 1. Be it declared by the Convention of the State of Texas, That Francis D. Allen, R. O. Love, R. W. Dowling, H. L. Allen, M. N. Brewster, H. Allen, Erastus Carter, S. Harper, J. M. Kaumheimer, J. S. Bachelder and S. J. Adams, of the city of Houston and county of Harris, and their associates and successors, are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name of the “Houston City Railroad Company;” by which name they may contract and be contracted with, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, issue bonds and borrow money, buy and sell real and personal esstate, and generally to do all acts necessary to carry out the objects of the company.
The principal office for the transaction of all business of the Company shall be in the city of Houston, and at which place alone they may be sued.

Section 2. The object of the Company is declared to be to build Street Railroads in the city of Houston, and also in such parts of the county of Harris as may be continuations of the same. And the Company under this act are authorized to build such roads in the manner specified, and on the streets named in a certain contract made and entered into on the 1st day of August, A. D., 1867, by and between the Mayor and Aldermen of the city of Houston and F. D. Allen and his associates; and may also be extended to embrace any other streets or roads that may hereafter be contracted for by said association with the parties aforesaid. And nothing in this act or any of the acts embraced herein, shall be so construed as to de-
Constitutional Convention.prive the city of Houston, or the corporators aforementioned, of any rights or privileges contained in said contract mentioned.

Section 3. The capital stock of said company shall be $500,000 di-
vided into 25,000 shares of $20, each share to be transferable by delivery of certificates. For every nine shares of stock issued to sub-
scribers, one share of like value shall be issued and delivered to the Cor-
porators as compensation for their services and labor in procuring sub-
scriptions and perfecting the organization of the Company. Should the object of the Company, in the estimation of the stockholders, be ac-
complished without the necessity of a sale of all the shares herein pro-
vided for, then any shares of said stock remaining unsold may, by a vote of the shareholders, be distributed pro rata as paid stock among the corporators and original stockholders. Shares may be disposed of for real estate at its cash value. No bonds shall ever be issued based upon the road or its appurtenances, but may be, if considered necessary, upon the real estate belonging to the Company.

Section 4. Subscription for stock shall be paid in such sums and at such times as may be called for by the Directors; and when any stock-
holders shall at any time make default in the payment of the assess-
ment of his stock, it shall be sold by the Secretary of the Company at public auction, after 30 days’ notice; which said sale shall be an absolute conveyance in fee simple of such stock to its purchaser, he also paying the remaining instalments of what may be due.

Section 5. The immediate government of the Company shall be vested in a board of nine Directors, the President to constitute one. The following named corporators and stockholders hereby appointed Directors, and are invested with all the rights and powers specified, viz:

M. DeChaumes, F. D. Allen, R. O. Love, J. C. C. Winch, R. E. Dowling, R. Allen, Erastus Carter, S. Harper, J. M. Kaumheimer, J. S. Batchelder, R. Green, jr., H. P. Roberts, Isaac Coleman and P. Rey-
nard, and M. DeChaumes is appointed the President and shall serve until superseded by their successor on the 4th Tuesday in December, A. D. 1869; and annually thereafter, an election for seven members of the Board of Directors shall be held at the office of the company, of which election, ten days’ previous notice shall be given. Two additional Di-
rectors shall be appointed by the corporators or their suc-
cessors from among themselves; or the Stockholders, together with the seven elected by the stockholders, shall constitute the full Board of nine. Any person shall be eligible to the office of Director who owns one share of stock. In all meetings of the stock-
holders each person shall be entitled to cast one vote for each
Ordinances Passed by theshare of the capital stock owned by him; possession of the certificate of stock being in all cases the evidence of such ownership. The Directors shall choose a President from their body, and either from the Board or stockholders a Secretary and Treasurer, or such other officers as they may deem necessary. In all vacancies occurring in the Board, the re-
maining Directors shall have power to fill from the stockholders. The Directors may establish by-laws, dispose of the funds of the company, establish regulations for the payment of the indebtedness, and generally have direction and control of the interests of the organi-
zation. They shall hold their offices for the term of one year, and until their successors are elected and take possession. They shall exhibit a condition of the affairs of the company at each annual meeting of the stockholders.

Section 6. The Secretary of the Company shall keep a register of the stock as originally issued. He shall issue certificates of all assessments as well as of stock, in such manner as the Board may direct.

Section 7. This act shall take effect from and after its passage, and remain in force twenty years; Provided, said Company shall build the road on the streets named and in the time agreed upon in their contract with the said city of Houston. And, provided, that the present stock-
holders in said company shall not be affected in their rights by anything herein contained. And it is further provided, That nothing in this act contained, shall annul or otherwise affect the work done and obliga-
tions entered into for the building of said road up to the present time, but the same shall be as effective as if done under the provisions of this charter.

Section 8. The object of this Act being to confine the contract here-
tofore granted by the city of Houston to the corporators therein named, it is further provided, That immediately after the passage of this act, the corporators or those having charge, shall turn over and deliver all books of subscription, assets and accounts, and the road and all its prop-
erty, into the hands of the directors named in this act, who are alone authorized to conduct the affairs of said Company, under such by-laws and regulations as may hereafter be adopted in accordance with this charter.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Authorizing the Secretary to draw a Warrant in favor of Fred Slaughter, for $1.50 per day for services as page.

div2.p:
Resolved, That the Secretary of this Convention be, and he is author-
ized to draw a warrant against the Contingent fund of this Convention, in favor of Fred Slaughter, for the sum of $1.50 per day, for his services as page or employe of this body, in carrying the mail of members of this Convention from this hall to the postoffice and back.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: For Port, of Entry, Sabine Pass, to be forwarded to the Congress of United States.

div2.p: Be it Resolved, by the people of Texas in Convention assembled:

1. That the Congress of the United States be, and are, hereby re-
quested to make by law, Sabine Pass, in the State of Texas, a port of entry.

2. That copies of this resolution, signed by the President of this Convention, and attested by the Secretary thereof, be forwarded to the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate of the United States.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Requesting Brevet Major General Reynolds to create a new Judicial District out of the Twenty-second and Fifteenth Judicial Districts of Texas.

div2.p:
Whereas, The necessities and convenience of the people of the Twenty-second and Fifteenth Judicial Districts of Texas demand special terms of the District Court, which cannot be held by the Judges thereof, as the regular terms of said court (as the districts are now constituted) require the official and regular services of said
Ordinances Passed by theJudges nearly the whole of the year; therefore, with the view of meet-
ing the wants of the people in this behalf,

Be it resolved by the delegates of the people of Texas in Convention assembled, That Brevet Major General J. J. Reynolds, commanding the Fifth Military District, comprising the State of Texas, be and is hereby respectfully requested to sub-divide the Twenty-second and Fif-
teenth Judicial Districts of the State of Texas, and from said districts create a new Judicial District, as follows, to wit: Houston, Nacog-
doches and Anderson counties from the Twenty-second District; and Trinity and Angelina counties from the Fifteenth District, to be called the Eighteenth Judicial District of Texas; and appoint a Judge and District Attorney for said new district, and authorize and require said Judge to hold one or more special terms (at least one) of the District Court in each of said counties, in each year, as he may direct; and that in case any of the courts of the proposed new district conflict with each other, that the Judge be authorized and required to postpone the regu-
lar terms of the court of such of said counties as may conflict, as he may direct.

Resolved, That a copy of this resolution, signed by the President and Secretary of this Convention, be forwarded to Major General J. J. Rey-
nolds, through the office of His Excellency, E. M. Pease, Provisional Governor of Texas.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Requesting an appropriation of twenty-five thousand dollars.

div2.p:
Whereas, The declaration passed on the — day of June, 1868, making an appropriation of one hundred and twenty-five thousand dol-
lars for the per diem pay and mileage of the members of the Convention, and for the per diem pay of the officers, and for the printing and con-
tingent expenses of the Convention, was only approved to the extent of one hundred thousand dollars by the Commander of the Fifth Military District.

And whereas, The said sum of one hundred thousand dollars is ex-
hausted, and the labors of the Convention are not yet completed, there-
fore

Be it resolved by the delegates of the people of Texas in Con-
vention assembled, That the Commander of the Fifth Military District be, and he is hereby respectfully requested to make his
Constitutional Convention.order approving the remainder of said appropriation, and authorizing and requiring the Comptroller to draw upon the Treasurer for said balance of twenty-five thousand dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, to meet the per diem pay of the members and officers of the Convention, and the mileage of the members, and the printing and con-
tingent expenses of the Convention, in the same manner and in the same terms as to vouchers, on which the one hundred thousand dollars was ordered to be paid.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Asking for the relinquishment of the ad-valorem tax of the county of Jefferson for 1868.

div2.p:
Section.—Be it declared by the people of Texas in Convention as-
sembled, That Brevet Major General J. J. Reynolds, commanding the Fifth Military District, be and is hereby requested to relinquish to the county of Jefferson, eight hundred and twenty-one dollars and sixty-
nine cents, the same being the ad-valorem tax of said county, assessed for the year 1868, to be used in repairing the court house of said county, recently damaged by lightning.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: To appropriate a sufficient sum of money for the purchase of books, etc., for the use of the Blind Asylum.

div2.p: Resolved, That the Provisional Government of the State of Texas be requested to appropriate a sufficient amount of money to purchase the necessary books, apparatus and instruments necessary for the wants of the blind pupils; for the repair and improvements suggested in the foregoing statement; and that the salary of the Superintendent be not less than the sum of fifteen hundred dollars per annum.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Incorporating the Jefferson, Marshal and Big Cypress Bayou Bridge Company.

div2.p:
Section 1. That George W. Keene, Aaron Grigsby, and W. H. John-
son, and such other persons as they may associate with themselves, and their successors, are hereby incorporated under the name of the Jeffer-
son, Marshal and Big Cypress Bayou Bridge Company, and under such name shall sue and be sued and have succession for thirty years.

Sec. 2. Said company shall have the right to construct a bridge, of iron or wood, across the Big Cypress Bayou, at a suitable point opposite the city of Jefferson, between said city of Jefferson and Marshal.

Sec. 3. Said company shall construct said bridge in a good and sub-
stantial manner, within five years from the first day of January, A. D. 1869, and shall keep the same in good repair for the term of thirty years from the completion thereof; and to be ready at all times to pass all passengers, carriages, wagons, teams and stock that may wish to cross on said bridge, and be responsible as common carriers under the law, for any loss of property in transit over said bridge.

Sec. 4. That said company shall be entitled to charge and receive, from the completion of said bridge, for the term of thirty years, the fol-
lowing tolls from all persons who may cross themselves or their prop-
erty, viz: Four horse or ox stage, or wagon, loaded, fifty cents; for six horse or ox stage, or wagon, sixty cents; and for each additional pair of horses, mules or oxen, attached to said wagon, ten cents; for man and horse, ten cents; single horse and buggy, twenty-five cents; two horse buggies, two horse or ox wagons, forty cents; other vehicles in proportion; footmen, five cents; cattle, five cents per head; hogs, sheep and goats, two cents per head; and other property in proportion to the above rates.

Sec. 5. That no other bridge or ferry shall be constructed or kept across the said Big Cypress Bayou or river, for the space of thirty years after the completion of the bridge, within a space of four miles on a straight line up and down said Big Cypress Bayou or river from said bridge, which said Jefferson, Marshal and Big Cypress Bridge Company may construct; provided, that in case the said bridge shall get out of repair, the said company shall be authorized to keep a ferry boat for the crossing of passengers over said bayou or river, until the said bridge is put in order.

Sec. 6. That any person crossing said bridge, or who by attempting to pass around said bridge, or otherwise attempt to evade the payment of the tolls herein allowed, when said company is authorized to demand and receive the same, shall forfeit and pay to said company for every such attempt, the sum of five dollars for each item attempted to be evaded, which may be recovered before any Justice of the Peace in whose jurisdiction such person may be found. Provided, that nothing herein contained shall be construed to prevent any person from crossing at any ford on said river, and that this declaration be and have effect from and after its passage; and all laws conflicting with this declaration are hereby repealed.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Declaring certain acts of the so-called Tenth and Eleventh Legislatures repealed.

div2.p:
1. Be it declared by the people of Texas, in Convention assembled, That an act of the so-called Tenth Legislature of the State of Texas, known as an act to punish certain offences committed on Sunday, ap-
proved December 16, 1863, and sections 1, 2, 3, 4, of an act of the so-
called Eleventh Legislature of the State of Texas, passed November 13, 1866, known as chapter CLXXVIII, an act amendatory of an act to punish certain offences committed on Sunday, approved December 16, 1863, be and are hereby declared repealed.

Be it further declared, That all prosecutions and judicial proceedings now pending in any courts of this State on the part of the State of Texas, for a violation of any of said acts, shall at once be abandoned, and that this declaration shall take effect from and after its passage.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: For the relief of the heirs of Sam. Houston, deceased.

div2.p:
Section 1. Be it declared and ordained, That the land certificate heretofore issued by the lawful authorities of the Republic of Texas,
Ordinances Passed by theon the twentieth of June, 1838, to General Sam. Houston, for military services from November, 1835, to October, 1836, for 1280 acres of land, being No. 3894, be, and the same is hereby approved and declared to be a valid and just claim, from its date, against the State of Texas; and the Commissioner of the General Land Office is hereby authorized to issue patent on the same to the heirs of Sam. Houston, deceased.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Requesting the Commanding General to relinquish the State tax of Montgomery county for the years 1867 and 1868.

div2.p:
Whereas, There is no jail in the county of Montgomery, and the employment of guards for prisoners is bankrupting said county; there-
fore,

Be it declared by the people of Texas assembled in Convention, That the Commanding General of the Fifth Military District of the United States be, and is hereby respectfully requested to relinquish the State taxes for the year 1867 not yet collected, and the taxes for the year 1868, to the said county of Montgomery, for the purpose of erecting a jail.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Authorizing the Governor to lease the State Penitentiary.

div2.p:
It is hereby declared by the people of Texas in Convention assembled, That the Provisional Governor of the State is hereby authorized and re-
quired to lease the State Penitentiary, with the labor of the convicts, for a term of not less than five nor more than ten years, upon the condi-
tions and with the limitations hereafter named.

The Penitentiary shall continue to be managed according to the present or future laws of the State, except that the office and duties of the financial agent, his bookkeeper and clerk, shall be dispensed with; and except, also, that the lessee or lessees shall have the right to direct what particular land of labor the convicts shall be employed
Constitutional Convention.in; but they shall not employ such labor at any other place than the Penitentiary.

The lessee or lessees shall furnish everything that is necessary for the support and maintenance of the Penitentiary and the convicts therein imprisoned; including the salaries of the officers and employes, which shall be paid quarterly; the transportation of convicts, and the amount required to be paid to convicts on their discharge.

They shall also keep the buildings in good repair; and shall construct such additional buildings and cells as, in the opinion of the Directors and Superintendent, may be necessary for the proper accommodation of the officers, employes and convicts; which shall be of durable materials, similar in style and equal in quality to the present buildings and cells; and they may, with the approval of Directors, erect such other walls and buildings, and make such changes and alterations in the present machinery, and procure such other machinery, as they may deem neces-
sary for the profitable employment of the labor of the convicts.

The lessee or lessees shall have the use of all land, buildings, ma-
chinery, tools and other property belonging to the Penitentiary, which are destined or used for the labor of the convicts; and shall have the control and direction of the labor of the convicts, subject, however, to all laws that have been, or may hereafter be enacted for the government and police of the Penitentiary. They shall have the right to introduce into the Penitentiary such skilled labor as they may think necessary to direct the labor of the convicts and give efficiency thereto.

An inventory and valuation of all the materials, machinery and prop-
erty of every description now belonging to the Penitentiary, except the land and buildings, shall be made by appraisers, one of whom shall be appointed by the Governor and the other by the lessee or lessees, with the right, on the part of the said appraisers, to appoint an umpire, in case they cannot agree; which property shall be receipted for by the lessee or lessees, at the valuation. At the expiration of the lease, a like inventory and valuation shall be made in the same manner of all the materials, machinery and property of every description then in use at the Penitentiary, including all new walls, buildings and cells that may have been constructed by the lessee or lessees, under the sanction of the Directors; but excluding the land and present buildings. At the expiration of the lease, the lessee or lessees shall be bound to have all the walls and build-
ings and machinery in good repair, and shall deliver them to the State in that condition. And the State shall be bound to pay them whatever excess there may be in the valuation of
Ordinances Passed by thethe materials, machinery and property, including any new walls, build-
ings and cells erected by them, which they may deliver to the State over and above the value of the property received from the State at the com-
mencement of their lease.

Whatever amount they (the lessee or lessees) may agree to pay the State for said lease, beyond the obligations herein required of them, shall be promptly paid according to the terms of their agreement.

The lessee or lessees shall be required to execute and deliver to the Governor, a bond with security to be approved by him, payable to the State of Texas, in the sum of fifty thousand dollars, conditioned for the faithful performance of the terms of their lease.
The State of Texas, by the Governor or Legislature, shall have the right to terminate said lease, if, at any time, the lessee or lessees shall fail to comply with their obligations under the same.

Sec. 2. The Commanding General of the Fifth Military District is requested to approve this declaration, and authorize the Penitentiary to be used in accordance therewith. And the Governor be empowered to insert such other terms in the contract as he may deem of interest to the State, which do not conflict with the rules herein prescribed.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute:
For the appointment of a special committee to inquire into the pro-
priety of admitting indigent persons into the asylums of the State.

div2.p:
Resolved, That a special committee be appointed to visit the Blind Asylum and Deaf and Dumb Asylum, with a view of inquiring into the propriety of admitting into either or both of these institutions, such number of indigent orphans as could be received therein, for educa-
tion and maintenance on the expense of the State, until an Orphan Asylum shall be established.

div2.head: RESOLUTIONS

opener.salute: Respecting the murder of Captain Martin D. Hart, First Texas Cavalry, by Confederate States officers.

div2.p:
Whereas, Hon. Martin D. Hart, of Hunt county, Texas, Captain of Company A, First Texas Cavalry, U. S. A., was, on the twenty-first day of January, 1863, at or near Fort Smith, Arkansas, most foully mur-
dered by a company of rebel officers and men, for no other crime than his loyalty to the Government; Therefore, be it

Resolved, That in the death of Captain Hart the loyal people of Texas lost a true and tried friend, and the people of his immediate sec-
tion an honorable and respectable citizen.

Resolved, That the loyal people of Texas deeply sympathize with the bereaved widow and children and relations of the deceased; and in be-
half of the loyal people we hereby offer our condolence in their sad be-
reavement.
Resolved, That a copy of these resolutions, signed by the Secretary and President, be forwarded to Mrs. Hart, at Greenville, Hunt county, Texas.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Granting Bounty to soldiers in the United States service in the late war.

div2.p: Whereas, During the late rebellion, many persons residing in Texas took up arms and did good service in the armies of the United States, as members of the first and second regiments of Texas Cavalry, and in other organizations; and
Whereas, The State of Texas has never heretofore recognized the services of these men in any public manner, as has been done by all the other States of the Union as to their soldiers; and

Whereas, These soldiers of Texas in the Union Army have been mercilessly slandered in their good names and plundered in their prop-
erty; be it, therefore, declared:

Section 1. That every officer and soldier, a resident of Texas at the time of volunteering, and who served as officer, non-com-
missioned officer or private, in the First and Second Regiments of Texas Cavalry, Union forces, purporting to be from Texas; or in
Ordinances Passed by theother organizations of Union forces, during the late rebellion; and who died in the said service, or were honorably discharged, shall receive a bounty of land from the State of Texas, as follows: those who served for a period of six months, or less, shall receive eighty acres of land. Those who served for a period of six months or over, and less than twelve months, shall receive one hundred and sixty acres of land. Those who served a period of twelve months or over, shall receive three hun-
dred and twenty acres of land. And the Legislature is directed to pro-
vide a bounty in money for each non-commissioned officer or private in any of the above organizations who served one year or more, $100; and for each non-commissioned officer or private who served less than one year, $50; said bounty to go to the heirs of some, in case of their de-
cease.

Sec. 2. That the Commissioner of the General Land Office of Texas shall issue to the persons entitled thereto, under this declaration, the certificates herein named, upon the presentation to him of the authen-
ticated discharge of the person claiming the same; and in case of a loss of said discharge, or a failure to get it, or the death of the applicant before discharge, said certificates for lands shall be issued upon a com-
pliance with such rules as the Commissioner of the General Land Office may make, which he is authorized to do.

Sec. 3. The wife, children, or mother and father, or any of them, according to the laws of descent and distribution of the State of Texas, shall take and receive the bounty, herein granted, of any officer, non-
commissioned officer or private who may have died without receiving the same; provided, that no officer or soldier, a resident of Texas at the time of his entering the service, and who entered organizations other than the said First and Second Texas Cavalry, Union forces, and re-
ceived a bounty in money or land from any State government or indi-
vidual fund, other than the United States bounty, shall be entitled to the bounty given by this declaration.

Sec. 4. The bounty here given shall not be subject to the debts of grantee, and the said certificates, in case of death, shall issue directly to the wife, children, or father and mother of the decedent, and may be located on any of the public domain in Texas.

Sec. 5. That the Secretary of State is hereby directed to procure from the Secretary of War of the United States a true copy or copies of the muster rolls of the Texas organizations in the service of the United States, and have the same filed in the Executive Office of the State of Texas.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Respecting the Houston Tap and Brazoria Railroad.

div2.p: Section 1. It is hereby declared by the Delegates of the people of Texas, in Convention assembled, that it shall be and is hereby made the duty of the present Provisional Governor of the State, to cause the Houston Tap and Brazoria Railroad to be sold for the payment of the indebtedness of the Company owning the same, to the Special School Fund of the State.

Sec. 2. As soon after the passage of this Ordinance as may be con-
sistent with his other official duties, the said Provisional Governor shall cause the said Railroad to be advertised for sale for sixty days in the following newspapers: the San Antonio Express, the Austin Republican, Flake’s Galveston Bulletin, the Houston Telegraph, and for at least forty days in some leading paper in the city of New York. The sale shall take place in front of the Capitol, in the city of Austin, between the hours of ten o’clock, A. M., and two o’clock, P. M. The sale shall be at public auction and under the direction of the Provisional Gov-
ernor. The sale shall be for cash, to be paid down in gold or silver-
money of the United States, or in its equivalent in United States cur-
rency, on the day of sale.

Sec. 3. As there may be some question as to the rights of a pur-
chaser under the existing law of the State, it is hereby declared that any purchaser of this road shall have the right either to run and manage said road, in conformity with the charter of the Company now owning the same, and subject to the laws of the State in the premises, or to take up and remove the iron from said road; but if the use of said road shall ever be discontinued and the iron removed from the same, then the franchises granted in the charter authorizing the construction of said road, shall revert to the State of Texas.

Sec. 4. If any person shall appear and bid for said road, and become the purchaser thereof on the day fixed for the sale, it shall be the duty of the Governor to give to such purchaser a certificate of the sale and purchase, which shall be signed by the Governor officially and attested by the Secretary of State, and the seal of the State; which said cer-
tificate shall be recorded in the office of the Secretary of State before being delivered to the purchaser; and such certificate shall vest full title to said road in the purchaser, with all the rights and privileges accorded by the charter of said road, by the laws of the State, and by this decla-
ration.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute:
Respecting the Texas and New Orleans Railroad and the Pacific Rail-
road.

div2.p:
Section 1. It is hereby Declared by the Delegates of the people of Texas, in Convention assembled, That it shall be, and is hereby made the duty of the present Provisional Governor of this State to cause the following named Railroads to be sold for the payment of the indebted-
ness of the Companies owning them respectively, to the Special School Fund of the State, to wit: the Texas and New Orleans Railroad and the Southern Pacific Railroad.

Sec. 2. It shall be the duty of the Governor, as soon after the passage of this declaration as may be consistent with his other official duties, to cause said Railroads to be advertised for sixty days in the following named newspapers, to wit: the San Antonio Express, the Austin Repub-
lican, Flake’s Galveston Bulletin, the Paris Vindicator, the National In-
dex, at Tyler, Smith county, and the McKinney Messenger, and also for forty days in some leading paper in the cities of New York, Philadel-
phia and Boston. The sale shall take place on the steps of the Capitol, in the city of Austin, between the hours of ten o’clock, A. M., and two o’clock, P. M., under the direction of the Governor. The said roads shall be sold separately. The sale shall transfer to the buyer all the property in the road and of the Company to which the bonds executed for the loan of the Special School Fund are a lien, as set forth in the 3d Section of the Act of the 13th of August, A. D. 1856, concerning the loan of the School Fund.

Sec. 3. For the purpose of the sale herein contemplated, it is hereby declared, that the Texas and New Orleans Railway Company was in-
debted to the Special School Fund on the 1st day of March, A. D. 1868, in the sum of $595,166,25, principal and interest; and that the South-
ern Pacific Railway Company was indebted to the Special School Fund, on the same day, in the sum of $202,625, principal and interest.

Sec. 4. The sale of these roads shall be at public auction, and if any person shall bid for either of said roads, the whole amount of the debt due by the Company owning the road to the Special School Fund, with interest to the day of sale, the whole amount to be paid down in coin, it shall be the duty of the Governor to accept such bid, and to cause the road in question to be knocked off to such purchaser, provided he cannot obtain a better bid in cash; but, if no person shall bid the whole amount due by the Companies
Constitutional Convention.owning said roads respectively, it shall be the duty of the Governor to bid for each of said roads the whole amount due by the Company to which the road belongs, to the School Fund, and thus purchase each of said roads for the State; and upon the making of such bid by the Gov-
ernor, and his public declaration that he purchases said roads for the State, said roads shall become the property of the State; and the Gov-
ernor shall, on the same day, file in the office of the Secretary of State a written declaration that he purchased said roads, or either or any of them, as the case may be, for the State; which declaration shall be at-
tested by the Secretary of State; and the seal of the State.

Sec. 5. If any person other than the Governor shall become the pur-
chaser of said roads, or either or any of them, then it shall be the duty of the Governor, after the payment of the price, to give to such pur-
chaser a certificate of sale, signed by himself officially and attested by the Secretary of State, using the seal of the State; which said certifi-
cate, after being recorded in the office of the Secretary of State, shall be delivered to the purchaser, and shall vest in said, purchaser full title to the road or roads so purchased, with all the rights, franchises, property, &c., set forth in the 3d Section of the Act of the 13th of August, 1856, concerning the loan of the School Funds.

Sec. 6. If the Governor shall purchase either, or any, or all of said roads for the State, he shall have, and is hereby vested with the power to re-sell either, or any, or all of said roads to any person, or company, or association of persons that can show, to the satisfaction of the Governor, the pecuniary ability to put said road or roads in complete running or-
der for the use of the public, and that shall also enter into contract with the Governor to put such road or roads in complete running order within a reasonable time; and any person, or company, or association of persons proposing so to contract with the Governor for the purchase of one or more of said roads, shall, in such contract, stipulate that the bonds of the former company, or companies, for the sums borrowed from the School Fund, shall continue to be a first lien on said road or roads for the amounts due said School Fund; and in making any such contract with the Governor, shall, as the representative of the State, stipulate that the party purchasing either, or any, or all of said roads shall have an extension of time for payment of the bonds of the former company or companies, for the amounts due the School Fund, of twenty years from the date of such contract; and such con-
tract shall also contain a stipulation that if the party purchasing either, or any, or all of said roads shall make default for the period of thirty days in the payment of interest upon said bonds,
Ordinances Passed by thethen the principal as well as the interest shall be deemed to be due, and the State shall have the right to proceed to sell the road or roads upon which the bonds so becoming due are a lien, in such manner as is now, or may hereafter be prescribed by law. Such re-sale and contract by the Governor shall subrogate the party purchasing to all the rights and privileges granted by the charter or charters of the company or com-
panies sold out, and shall subject the party purchasing to all of the pro-
visions of the laws of the State, as fully as the sold out company or com-
panies was, or were. And any person, or persons who may purchase said roads, or either of them from the Governor under the provisions of this Section, shall be required to deposit in the Treasury of the State, for the Texas and New Orleans Railroads, the sum of one hundred thousand dollars in United States currency or bonds, and for the South-
ern Pacific Road the sum of seventy thousand dollars in United States currency, or bonds; said deposits shall be upon the consideration which shall be expressed in the contracts, that when either of said roads shall have expended an amount equal to the amount deposited in making proper repairs upon the roads, said purchaser shall have the right to withdraw one-half of the amount deposited upon the certificate of the Governor; and when a further sum equal to the whole amount of the sum originally deposited shall be expended by the purchaser in making proper repairs on said road, then said purchaser shall have the right to withdraw the remainder of the deposit upon the certificate of the Governor.

And it shall also be stipulated that if the purchaser making the de-
posit as above provided, shall fail to make proper repairs upon the road purchased, equal in value to the amount deposited, within six months from the time such person shall obtain possession of the road purchased, then the sum deposited shall be absolutely forfeited to the State.

Sec. 7. If the Governor shall not make any re-sale of said roads, or either, or any of them before the first day of the meeting of the next Legislature of the State, then his power to re-sell said roads, or such of them as at that time have not been re-sold by him, shall cease, and it shall be the duty of the Legislature to make such disposition of such reads, or road, as may be the property of the State, as will best protect the Special School Fund and subserve the interests of the public.

Sec. 8. In the event that the Governor shall purchase any, or either of these roads for the State, as herein before provided, he shall have authority to take possession of the roads, or road purchased, and to appoint a receiver, or receivers, to control and man-
Constitutional Convention.age the same for the State under his direction, until a re-sale shall be made, or until the Legislature shall otherwise direct.

Sec. 9. In the event of a purchase of these roads, or either of them from the Governor, under the provisions of the 6th Section of this declaration, nothing, in this declaration contained, and nothing in the contract which the purchaser may enter into with the Governor, shall be construed or understood to deprive the Legislature of the power to control said roads by law, or to make any further agreement with such purchaser as may be deemed beneficial to the roads or to the public, and conducive to the security of the School Fund.

Sec. 10. It shall be the duty of the Governor to recite this declara-
tion in the advertisement of said roads for sale.

div2.head: RESOLUTION

opener.salute: Respecting a Committee to remain in session during the recess and for other purposes.

div2.p:
Resolved, That Messrs. Munroe, Thomas, Varnell and Watrous, mem-
bers of this Convention be, and they are hereby appointed a Committee, as provided for in a resolution of the Convention, to act in conjunction with the President, in convening this body at an earlier day than that to which it will stand adjourned from the 31st August, if the public in-
terest should require it. And during the recess the Secretary shall safely keep the journals and records of the Convention, together with declarations, resolutions and reports as may be intrusted to him by the members, and shall act as Secretary to the Committee created by this resolution.
The Secretary shall receive his per diem during the recess, and all other officers and employees shall not receive pay during the recess.
The members of the Convention shall receive no per diem during the recess.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute:
Levying a special tax for the payment of the per diem pay and mileage of members; the per diem pay of the officers and the contingent ex-
penses of the Reconstruction Convention.

div2.p: Be it declared by the people of Texas in Convention assembled’ That the Assessors and Collectors of the several counties of this State, are required to collect a tax of twenty cents on the hundred dollar’s worth of property, assessed for State taxes for the year 1868, to pay fees, salary, compensation of delegates and agents, and contingent expenses of this Convention, which assembled by virtue of an act of the Congress of the United States, which passed March 23, 1867, entitled “an Act supplemental to an act entitled ‘an act to provide for the more efficient government of the rebel States, passed March 2, 1867, and to facilitate restoration.’ ”

Section 1. That the taxes herein levied shall be collected and re-
turned by the first day of December, 1868, and the Comptroller shall take all necessary steps and prescribe rules to insure the prompt and efficient collection of the same.

Sec. 2. That the sum of five thousand dollars is hereby appropriated, or so much thereof as may be necessary for the purchase of books, print-
ing blanks, purchase of stationery, clerk’s hire, and for contingencies that may arise which are necessary to carry into effect this declaration.

Sec. 3. The Comptroller is hereby required to keep a separate account of all taxes received under this declaration, and the Assessors and Col-
lectors shall be entitled to commission for collecting the taxes herein levied, as follows: at eight per cent. on the first thousand dollars; at five per cent. on the second thousand dollars; at four per cent. on the third, fourth and fifth thousand dollars; at three per cent. on the sixth, seventh, eighth, ninth and tenth thousand dollars, and one per cent. on all sums over ten thousand dollars.
Sec. 4. The taxes herein levied shall be collected in the same manner as is now provided for the collection of State taxes by the laws in force.

Sec. 5. That all appropriations drawn from the State Treasury for the rise of this Convention, shall, be reimbursed the State out of the taxes herein levied, and this declaration, shall be in force from its pas-
sage.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Authorizing the Governor to invest the School Fund of the Treasury in U. S. Gold bearing Bonds.

div2.p: Whereas, There is now in the Treasury of the State of Texas, the sum of fifty-nine thousand four hundred and seventy-nine dollars in specie, belonging to the Common School Fund, which is drawing no interest.

Therefore, Be it declared by the people of Texas in Convention as-
sembled, that the Provisional Governor be, and he is hereby authorized and required to invest the sum of fifty-eight thousand dollars of said amount in United States gold bearing Bonds, so that said sum maybe drawing interest thereon, for the benefit of the Common School Fund of the State.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Incorporating the Navasota, Washington and Brazos Bridge Company.

div2.p:
Section 1. Be it declared by this Convention, That C. T. Harn, and such other persons as he may associate with himself, are hereby incor-
porated under the name of the “Navasota, Washington and Brazos Bridge Company,” and under such name shall sue and be sued, and have succession for thirty years.

Sec. 2. Said Company shall have the right to construct a bridge of iron or wood across the Brazos river, at or near where the road from Navasota crosses the Brazos river, to the town of Washington, in Wash-
ington county, Texas.

Sec. 3. Said Company shall construct said bridge in a good and sub-
stantial manner, within three years from the 1st day of January, A. D., 1869, and shall keep the same in good repair for the term of (30) thirty years from the completion thereof, and to be ready at all times to pass all passengers, carriages, wagons, teams and stock that may wish to cross on said bridge, and be responsible as common carriers under the law for any loss of property in transit over said bridge.

Sec. 4. That said Company shall be entitled to charge and receive from the completion of said bridge, for the term of thirty
Ordinances Passed by theyears, the following tolls from all persons who may cross themselves, or their property, viz: four-horse or ox stage, or wagon, loaded, fifty cents: for six-horse or ox stage, or wagon, loaded, seventy-five cents; and for each additional pair of horses, mules, or oxen, attached to said wagons, twenty-five cents; for man and horse, fifteen cents; single horse and buggy, thirty cents; two-horse buggies, two-horse or ox wagon, fifty cents; other vehicles in proportion; footmen, five cents; cattle, five cents per head; hogs, sheep and goats, two cents per head, and other property not mentioned in proportion to the above rates.

Sec. 5. That no other bridge shall be constructed across the said Brazos river for the space of thirty years, within three miles, on a straight line up and down said Brazos river, from said bridge, which said Navasota, Washington and Brazes Bridge Company may construct, and this declaration be and have effect from and after its passage.

div2.head: DECLARATION

opener.salute: Granting the Mexican and Gulf Railroad Company an extension of time for the completion of the second twenty-five miles of road.

div2.p: Whereas, The San Antonio and Mexican Gulf Railroad Company (without aid from the School Fund) constructed and equipped their road from Lavaca to Victoria, and kept the same in successful operation until destroyed by the rebel General Magruder, and
